Final Fantasy VII Rebirth isn't just a sequel; it's a staggering exercise in ambition and scale, taking the foundation built by Remake and expanding it across a breathtaking, semi-open world. This is a game that feels truly maximalist, delivering a vast, emotional experience that succeeds primarily through its unparalleled character depth and incredible presentation, even if its sheer volume of content occasionally trips it up.

The absolute highlight of Rebirth lies in its main cast. The development team has poured an astonishing amount of detail into Cloud, Tifa, Aerith, Barret, the rest of the party members, as well as many main NPCs. The nuanced expressions, the casual dialogue, and the hundreds of optional character moments flesh out these icons in ways the original PS1 classic could only imply. Their camaraderie and conflict form the emotional bedrock of the entire journey, making every victory, joke, and tragedy resonate profoundly.

This character work is consistently elevated by the game’s spectacular presentation. Square Enix’s reputation for excellence in this area is on full display, but the cutscenes here deserve special praise. They are cinematic masterpieces, blending breathtaking visual fidelity with masterful direction and voice acting. Whether they are advancing the grand, world-shaking plot or delivering intimate, quiet character beats, these sequences are some of the best in modern gaming, capturing the drama and flair that the Final Fantasy series is known for.

However, as with its predecessor, Rebirth continues to diverge from the established canon. The story, while covering the core plot points of the original game's second act, introduces significant differences and narrative complexities, heavily involving the mysterious "Whispers" and introducing concepts that challenge the nature of fate and time. For longtime fans of the original FF7, this revisionist approach, which started in Remake, keeps the narrative unpredictable, but some may find the added layers unnecessarily convoluted.

The largest new element is the sprawling, multi-zone open world. While beautiful and vibrant, the structure of populating these zones with various activities can feel a little too familiar. A significant portion of the optional content—particularly the work for Chadley, such as climbing communication towers and clearing World Intel objectives—follows a repetitive "Ubisoft Formula" checklist. While the rewards (powerful Materia, better summons) make these activities compelling, the sheer volume and routine nature of these tasks can become tedious, occasionally slowing the momentum of the main story.

Despite these moments of bloat, Final Fantasy VII Rebirth is a phenomenal achievement. It is a massive, confident, and spectacular continuation of one of gaming's greatest stories. The emotional core is solid, the action combat is superb, and the ambition on display is undeniable. Ultimately, Rebirth is a monumental achievement, delivering a powerful and emotional spectacle that every (J)RPG fan should experience.

FF7RB has received strong praise overall, with critics highlighting its expansive world, engaging combat and ambitious storytelling. This game left me with such mixed feelings - both love and frustration.

The graphics are detailed and beautiful. All heroines look stunning, even the random NPCs on the street are attractive.

Summons, materia, and skill books—these essential items are tightly bound to the open-world checklist system. The Mog's Cabin shop hides some of the best gear, which means players are forced to grind through the checklist whether they like it or not.  

Characters can permanently learn weapon skills by building proficiency, but many weapons are locked behind mini-games at their highest difficulty levels. 

Materia combinations and party setups create endless possibilities for growth, yet SE still refuses to provide a loadout save function. With limited materia and stat books in a first playthrough, anyone wanting to train two or three teams—or even just experiment with multiple builds for one team—must tediously reassign materia and respec skills one by one. Team switching exists, but loadout saving does not.  

On the other hand, the quality of side quests (marked with green icons) is among the best I've seen in years. Some guide exploration, others deepen character development, and many expand the world's lore. Each quest has its own narrative arc, unique gameplay, and even dedicated background music. Believe it or not, the game features hundreds of tracks in total. By limiting each map to four to six green-icon quests, the developers raised the overall quality—an excellent design choice.  

The open world itself was split into chunks, and for most of the game I assumed they were just separate maps stitched together with background loading. Only in Chapter 12, when the Tiny Bronco transforms into a ship and sails across the vast ocean, did I realize FF7RB actually has one continuous world map, artificially segmented by design. Unfortunately, by the time players discover this, the game is already nearing its finale.  

Still, there are moments of brilliance. Players can ride different chocobos—mountain birds to climb peaks, flying birds to soar through the skies—command parades in the coastal city of Junon, and witness Lovelace's birth in the dazzling Gold Saucer. These are exactly the kinds of experiences I imagined a remake should deliver.  

Yet the repetition of meaningless checklists and mini-games, the lack of optimization polish, and the imbalance between main and side content hold the game back. If SE had trimmed the filler, refined performance, and better balanced narrative with exploration, FF7RE could have come much closer to perfection.  

As a MUST-play for fans of JRPGs and the FF series, offering a rich, immersive experience that expands the beloved classic. While not flawless, its ambition and artistry make it one of SE's most impressive modern titles.

You're either invested enough already from FF7 Remake to buy Rebirth, or you're not and you should play Remake instead, or you didn't like Remake and so shouldn't play Rebirth at all. No matter what your decision is probably already made before you read this. 

That said, Rebirth IS a solid sequel to Remake. It takes the extremely linear version of FF7 found there and expands it greatly to cover the bulk of the original game's world exploration phase that takes up the rest of Disc 1, essentially. In converting "Overworld" to "Open World" the game brings said world to life, and largely follows the Remake's philosophy of maximally expanding on every single environment, character, or moment from the original game. Which makes this just a HUGE experience at the very least.

So long as you have the time to explore this expansive Planet and like playing lots of mini-games, Rebirth does a fine job with this embiggened scope. You'll laugh, you might cry, and run the gamut on the emotions in-between while you have fun with the now well refined combat system that runs a fine balance between spectacle, twitch reflex and tactical depth. I kind of feel that enemy HP bars could be a bit longer in the mid game, as despite having tons of content to explore, the game is balanced at maybe doing half of it, so completionists like myself get a bit overpowered by then. There are enough bonus challenges and side bosses to serve the difficulty guys like me want, just as a side dish rather than the main course. 

The story makes some . . . choices. Especially at the end. They largely seem to exist to confuse the ultimate outcome for the next game in the series and build anticipation, because of course nothing gets truly resolved in this installment so it's basically impossible to judge the merits of these choices without knowing what the ultimate end actually is. If the next game pays off these choices well, then these choices are brilliant!. If it doesn't, then these choices were awful. But there's no way to actually know which it will be until then!

For my part, the decisions made here have me interested enough to come back one more time at least to see this trilogy to its conclusion (hopefully its only a trilogy and Squeenix doesn't try to milk it and split the next game into two installments or something silly like that). So I guess I'd say the choices made in Rebirth at least ultimately worked to keep this player invested. But they also don't work to totally assuage fears that this could all pan out really poorly. 

Rebirth ultimately steers the whole Remake trilogy into what potentially might be the same problems the Mass Effect trilogy ended up running into - hyping up a scenario and writing itself into a corner that few could ever successfully pay off. I REALLY hope that's not the case, but only time will tell. 

Until then though, this is a good game, and should be played by all who liked the one that came before it, regardless of whether or not its sequel flubs it at the finish line.

(oh, and the soundtrack in particular is truly excellent - if nothing else, Rebirth's makes for another banger Squeenix OST)

This is a case where I'd like to give this a "maybe" recommendation. Since that's not an option and there are already so many positive ones, I'll tilt towards the "No" side. If I didn't love the originals as much as I do, I think I would have been pretty unimpressed with the whole package, even if it's "fun enough I guess" as a whole and definitely has some high points.

The visuals and soundtrack are incredible, probably the only part I can say I like without reservation. The various regions are beautifully realized, the music always serves the mood, and the cutscenes give superb definition to moments from the original that just can't really be well conveyed with so few polygons.

The gameplay on the other hand is pretty meh for me. First, the combat. I have a feeling this was a combination of 1) Doing all the side content as soon as it was available (as I was aiming for full completion) and 2) Not setting difficulty to Dynamic. The result is I ended up pretty over-leveled, and just mashing/ATB-spamming (2+ enemies? Triple-Slash. 1 enemy? Braver.) my way through fights was faster than anything else even if it's not as "resource efficient". Functionally infinite cure/revive magic takes care of the rest. You can mess with Materia for fun but you'll probably be so strong you won't have to optimize much, if at all. Doing all the Protorelic side quests grants access to the most fun fight in the game (and a few of the most annoying ones), but I won't spoil those. If you play on dynamic or do less side content YMMV. On the bright side, the block/perfect-block/dodge stuff feels a LOT better than it did in REMAKE. I just don't find the system very satisfying compared to other games. 

On the non-combat gameplay side, storyline quests and minigames (like the Junon march, for example), are pretty fun, or at least cute. Unfortunately this feels like it encompasses about 25% of the game's content. The vast, vast majority is the worst kind of Ubislop meme-tower checklist garbage coupled with a baffling number of minigames that aren't particularly fun or memorable. Each region's side content feels pretty cookie-cutter, and the character side quests are basically the same bland fetch-quest or kill X monster activities, with a short character interaction thrown in between each stage of the quest. The character stuff is cute I guess, but the later in the game you are, the more this all feels like a drag. The most fun way to play this game is probably to do just the character side quests for the characters you like, and any side content that happens to be along the way (so you're not under-leveled). Otherwise just tunnel-vision the main story, as everything you're skipping is boring filler. Throw in the Protorelics if you want those aforementioned extra fights, but be aware this is gonna commit you to some pretty rough minigames. 

The story is what I'm torn on the most. The characters (except for Aerith, who for wacky spoiler-y lore reasons ends up kind of *off*) are all true to their OG selves and they're as endearing as ever in a goofy anime way, of course. The story is too, until it decides it wants to do silly convoluted timeline nonsense. The result is a story that is the most awkward combination of 1:1 retelling and rewrite. I would have strongly preferred that they EITHER fully commit to retelling the original story, or fully commit to writing a different one using the same world, characters, and setup. What we got is a 90% retelling where the 10% difference just brings everything down. The ending of REMAKE teases that the writers have granted themselves freedom to do whatever they want (which they already had) and it would have been fine for them to exercise it. But then they chose to do not much of anything different anyway. As a result, the story is mostly good insofar as the original is good. A few key areas (like the Golden Saucer) are elevated to a wonderful new level. Almost the entire end of the game is a disappointing clusterf*** that pretty much ruins the emotional impact of the scenes it retells. Also, If someone hasn't played FF7 OG and Crisis Core or something, I'm not sure ANYTHING involving Zack makes sense. It's definitely not necessary (which even Squeenix knows, because you can completely skip the Zack chapters on 2nd playthrough lmao).

I want to love this game so bad. It has a TON of great features. The battle system is fantastic (Though I prefer turn-based combat). The voice acting is amazing. The minigames are great as well. 

However, there is a glaring, critically lethal problem with this game. The Story.

I played the original back in the 90's. It was transformative in my understanding of what videogames to be and do. It was the first videogame that I cried to.

However, they have reworked the story in such a way that all the things that make the original game legendary and meaningful, they have completely changed. Moments that made you cry in the old game now feel hollow. Villains, especially Sephiroth, have been stripped of their aura and mystique. Scenes meant to be solemn, like Barrett and Dyne, are now wildly sensationalized. I heard one person say it like this, and I totally agree: Final Fantasy VII is now Kingdom Hearts.

I thought the first game had a crazy ending, but I was hopeful. I generally despise time bending, time travel, and alternate timelines, and this game embodies all of the things I hate about that story trope. 

What seems to be the case is that the current Square Enix team tried to make this game all things to all people, and so it ends up being nothing for anybody.

A few other notes are that some of the game mechanics are extremely repetative. Scanning locations, gathering things, and other such mini-missions are exactly the same in every single region. This was fine in the first few places, but then it got old quickly.

In sum, FFVII Rebirth COULD have been a sensational game, building off of all the things that made the original incredible, and improving on things that were dated. Instead, they changed everything. This problem is rife in modern media; the hubris of modern creators to rewrite things they believe they can improve without any true intellectual understanding of what made the original great to begin with. FFVII was legendary because it dared to go all in on its themes, and it didn't apologize. Rebirth apologizes constantly and commits to nothing, but still wants you feel. I'm sorry, but that's not how it works.

Si bien Final Fantasy VII Rebirth intenta expandir el universo del remake con un mundo más amplio, en mi experiencia la trama se siente floja y, aunque tiene momentos interesantes, el concepto final resulta trillado y forzado. Personalmente considero que FFVII Remake logra mucho mejor en este apartado.

La evolución de los personajes es aceptable y aporta cierta profundidad, pero el sistema de exploración me pareció aburridísimo. El mundo abierto está lleno de minijuegos y misiones secundarias que se sienten demasiado alejadas de la historia principal, lo que rompe el ritmo narrativo.

En cuanto a gráficos, arte y música, el juego destaca y es innegable el esfuerzo técnico, pero aun así no logra convencerme para darle una valoración positiva. La mezcla entre mundo abierto y secciones más lineales enfocadas en la historia no termina de funcionar; en mi opinión, el juego debió centrarse más en la narrativa que en expandir un mundo abierto poco atractivo.

El sistema de combate lo encontré desordenado y menos satisfactorio que los clásicos por turnos, lo que refuerza mi sensación de que el título no logra equilibrar innovación con jugabilidad sólida.

Conclusión: En términos generales, no recomiendo Final Fantasy VII Rebirth. Tiene apartados técnicos notables, pero la historia floja, el mundo abierto aburrido y el combate poco convincente hacen que la experiencia no esté a la altura de lo esperado.

I have far too many thoughts on this game. Some things I like, some things I loathe. I am too far in to stop now and I cling to the fun things about it to make up for how badly botched the vast majority of this games' story is.

These Final Fantasy 7 remakes need to be studied. They are the most bizarrely, uniquely incompetent exercises in pointlessness in gaming history. We waited 20 years, and this is what we got. We live in a stupid age of stupid corporate decisions.

These games are not remakes. They're bizarre works of coke-addled nonsense. Besides the opening and the section in Kalm, the plot is completely different. The only thing that remains from the original is the order in which you visit the locations. Every story beat is changed for the worse. They say the original creator of FF7 was involved, but that's a terrible idea. They told the story 20 years ago - why would they tell the same story again? It's one thing to make some slight changes, but they change *everything*. The opening chapter in Nibelheim is the only part that delivers on the promise of a remake of the classic story. Everything else is completely shot to hell.

If you loved Final Fantasy 7, avoid it like the plague. If you never played the original, then you won't have a clue what's going on. I played the original and a bunch of the other games in the bloated canon of FF7 and even I'm bewildered at some of the story elements.

This came out in 2024. Remake in 2020. They may have modern graphics, but they play like PS2 games. It's *shockingly* primitive.

It's enjoyable 40% of the time as a bizarre comedy masterpiece, but that charm wears thing the further you get into the game. It's hard to keep laughing when the legacy of something so beloved is being trampled on repeatedly.

I cannot believe that this is the game we got. I cannot believe this much money was spent on such incredible incompetence.
